t: John 11
Now*p a certain man was sick, named Lazarus, of Bethany, the town of Mary and her sister Martha.
(It*p was that Mary which anointed the Lord with ointment, and wiped his feet with her hair, whose brother Lazarus was sick.)
Therefore*p his sisters sent unto him, saying, Lord, behold, he whom thou lovest is sick.
When*p Jesus heard that, he said, This*r sickness*r is*r not*r unto*r death,*r but*r for*r the*r glory*r of*r God,*r that*r the*r Son*r of*r God*r might*r be*r glorified*r thereby.*r
Now*p Jesus loved Martha, and her sister, and Lazarus.
When*p he had heard therefore that he was sick, he abode two days still in the same place where he was.
Then*p after that saith he to his disciples, Let*r us*r go*r into*r Judaea*r again.*r
His*p disciples say unto him, Master, the Jews of late sought to stone thee; and goest thou thither again?
Jesus*p answered, Are*r there*r not*r twelve*r hours*r in*r the*r day?*r If*r any*r man*r walk*r in*r the*r day,*r he*r stumbleth*r not,*r because*r he*r seeth*r the*r light*r of*r this*r world.*r
But*rp if*r a*r man*r walk*r in*r the*r night,*r he*r stumbleth,*r because*r there*r is*r no*r light*r in*r him.*r
These*p things said he: and after that he saith unto them, Our*r friend*r Lazarus*r sleepeth;*r but*r I*r go,*r that*r I*r may*r awake*r him*r out*r of*r sleep.*r
Then*p said his disciples, Lord, if he sleep, he shall do well.
Howbeit*p Jesus spake of his death: but they thought that he had spoken of taking of rest in sleep.
Then*p said Jesus unto them plainly, Lazarus*r is*r dead.*r
And*rp I*r am*r glad*r for*r your*r sakes*r that*r I*r was*r not*r there,*r to*r the*r intent*r ye*r may*r believe;*r nevertheless*r let*r us*r go*r unto*r him.*r
Then*p said Thomas, which is called Didymus, unto his fellowdisciples, Let us also go, that we may die with him.
Then*p when Jesus came, he found that he had lain in the grave four days already.
Now*p Bethany was nigh unto Jerusalem, about fifteen furlongs off:
And*p many of the Jews came to Martha and Mary, to comfort them concerning their brother.
Then*p Martha, as soon as she heard that Jesus was coming, went and met him: but Mary sat still in the house.
Then*p said Martha unto Jesus, Lord, if thou hadst been here, my brother had not died.
But*p I know, that even now, whatsoever thou wilt ask of God, God will give it thee.
Jesus*p saith unto her, Thy*r brother*r shall*r rise*r again.*r
Martha*p saith unto him, I know that he shall rise again in the resurrection at the last day.
Jesus*p said unto her, I*r am*r the*r resurrection,*r and*r the*r life:*r he*r that*r believeth*r in*r me,*r though*r he*r were*r dead,*r yet*r shall*r he*r live:*r
And*rp whosoever*r liveth*r and*r believeth*r in*r me*r shall*r never*r die.*r Believest*r thou*r this?*r
She*p saith unto him, Yea, Lord: I believe that thou art the Christ, the Son of God, which should come into the world.
And*p when she had so said, she went her way, and called Mary her sister secretly, saying, The Master is come, and calleth for thee.
As*p soon as she heard that, she arose quickly, and came unto him.
Now*p Jesus was not yet come into the town, but was in that place where Martha met him.
The*p Jews then which were with her in the house, and comforted her, when they saw Mary, that she rose up hastily and went out, followed her, saying, She goeth unto the grave to weep there.
Then*p when Mary was come where Jesus was, and saw him, she fell down at his feet, saying unto him, Lord, if thou hadst been here, my brother had not died.
When*p Jesus therefore saw her weeping, and the Jews also weeping which came with her, he groaned in the spirit, and was troubled,
And*p said, Where*r have*r ye*r laid*r him?*r They said unto him, Lord, come and see.
Jesus*p wept.
Then*p said the Jews, Behold how he loved him!
And*p some of them said, Could not this man, which opened the eyes of the blind, have caused that even this man should not have died?
Jesus*p therefore again groaning in himself cometh to the grave. It was a cave, and a stone lay upon it.
Jesus*p said, Take*r ye*r away*r the*r stone.*r Martha, the sister of him that was dead, saith unto him, Lord, by this time he stinketh: for he hath been dead four days.
Jesus*p saith unto her, Said*r I*r not*r unto*r thee,*r that,*r if*r thou*r wouldest*r believe,*r thou*r shouldest*r see*r the*r glory*r of*r God?*r
Then*p they took away the stone from the place where the dead was laid. And Jesus lifted up his eyes, and said, Father,*r I*r thank*r thee*r that*r thou*r hast*r heard*r me.*r
And*rp I*r knew*r that*r thou*r hearest*r me*r always:*r but*r because*r of*r the*r people*r which*r stand*r by*r I*r said*r it,*r that*r they*r may*r believe*r that*r thou*r hast*r sent*r me.*r
And*p when he thus had spoken, he cried with a loud voice, Lazarus,*r come*r forth.*r
And*p he that was dead came forth, bound hand and foot with graveclothes: and his face was bound about with a napkin. Jesus saith unto them, Loose*r him,*r and*r let*r him*r go.*r
Then*p many of the Jews which came to Mary, and had seen the things which Jesus did, believed on him.
But*p some of them went their ways to the Pharisees, and told them what things Jesus had done.
Then*p gathered the chief priests and the Pharisees a council, and said, What do we? for this man doeth many miracles.
If*p we let him thus alone, all men will believe on him: and the Romans shall come and take away both our place and nation.
And*p one of them, named Caiaphas, being the high priest that same year, said unto them, Ye know nothing at all,
Nor*p consider that it is expedient for us, that one man should die for the people, and that the whole nation perish not.
And*p this spake he not of himself: but being high priest that year, he prophesied that Jesus should die for that nation;
And*p not for that nation only, but that also he should gather together in one the children of God that were scattered abroad.
Then*p from that day forth they took counsel together for to put him to death.
Jesus*p therefore walked no more openly among the Jews; but went thence unto a country near to the wilderness, into a city called Ephraim, and there continued with his disciples.
And*p the Jews' passover was nigh at hand: and many went out of the country up to Jerusalem before the passover, to purify themselves.
Then*p sought they for Jesus, and spake among themselves, as they stood in the temple, What think ye, that he will not come to the feast?
Now*p both the chief priests and the Pharisees had given a commandment, that, if any man knew where he were, he should shew it, that they might take him.
